+WeirdCityCitizen It may be advisable for you to conduct more thorough 
research into the matter.

The historical facts are that Theodor Herzl of the Zionist movement in 
Europe in the late 19th century welcomed the rise of anti-Jewish feeling in 
Germany as he considered it a factor which would aid the Zionist project of 
relocating German Jews to Palestine and establishing the Zionist state of 
Israel. 

The two reactionary movements of Zionism and Nazism shared the view that 
German Jews were living in that country as a ‘foreign race’ and that the 
racial divide was essential to maintain. While in 1912, the first president 
of Israel, Chaim Weizmann said "Germany already has too many Jews". Thus, 
the rise of Hitler and the Nazis was never at all challenged by the Zionist 
Movement in Europe. 

While some Zionists such as Stephen Wise of the American Jewish Congress 
stated in 1934 that the 'Galuth' (Jewish communities outside of Palestine) 
were expendable in light of the larger picture of establishing the Jewish 
state in Palestine. (Rabbi Wise, The New Palestine (14 February 1934), p 
5-7). Nazi SS Officer Adolf Eichmann had read Herzl’s book, Der Judenstaat, 
and also studied Hebrew. In their trip report, the two SS officers 
(Eichmann and Hagen) paraphrased Polkes’s message to them: "The Zionist 
state must be established by all means and as soon as possible." (Polkehn, 
Klaus, “The Secret Contacts: Zionism and Nazi Germany 1933-41”, Journal of 
Palestine Studies (Spring 1976), p 337). They also oth reported that: "… in 
Jewish nationalist circles people were very pleased with the radical German 
policy, since the strength of the Jewish population in Palestine would be 
so far increased thereby that in the foreseeable future the Jews could 
reckon upon numerical superiority over the Arabs in Palestine." (Hohne, 
Heinz, The Order of the Death’s Head, p 337).

Zionists therefore were indifferent to the slaughter of German Jews and in 
some cases thought the numbers to be exaggerated. Not to mention the 
Ha'avara Agreement in 1933 between Zionists and Nazis.

This is well-documented historically, only jonny-come-lately political and 
media spin doctors would argue otherwise. The fact that these people have 
no idea about Herzl is telling in and of itself. More serious historians

The Grand Mufti of Jerusalem (Haj Amin al-Husseini) helped the Nazis gain 
support among Muslims, but the meeting he had with Hitler didn't result in 
any agreement from the Nazi side. Incidentally, this meeting occurred in 
1941, five years after he had been dismissed as Mufti and while he was 
living in exile from Palestine to avoid being arrested. At that meeting, he 
asked Hitler to sign a declaration that the Zionist project in Palestine 
was illegal. Hitler refused on the grounds that the time wasn't right.

As to your broader point, if there had been an agreement between Arabs and 
Nazis, Arabs might find it uncomfortable or offensive to mention it, but I 
agree that this shouldn't make it completely off limits to mention. I do 
think there are contexts where it is inappropriate to make true statements 
though. It's fine to tell someone that their butt is big if they ask you 
for your opinion, but mentioning it out of the blue isn't exactly polite, 
even if true. Likewise, pointing out that Hitler was a vegetarian in an 
argument against vegetarianism, or going to a dog show and pointing out 
that Hitler also liked dogs would be inappropriate. You'd be speaking the 
truth, but I would object to anyone attempting taint these things by 
association rather than arguing their merits. Hitler also breathed air so 
there are certain things that it is okay to have in common with him.

taint Zionism in the same way. It wouldn't entirely surprise me if 
Livingstone wanted to do that on some level, but again, 'Zionist' doesn't

Zionism, I would hope that it's because of the moral consequences of the 
movement rather than whatever Hitler's stance was towards it. I get that 
antisemites often attempt to mask their antisemitism by claiming only to

is in this category. I think he's genuinely opposed to Zionism and the 
Israeli government's treatment of Palestinians and not antisemitic.
